title: Timekeeping System
description: Understand the unique Ethiopian time system with its two 12-hour cycles based on sunrise and sunset.

parts.title: Dawn to Dusk: Understanding Ethiopian Time Cycles

data.text: The Ethiopian timekeeping system divides the day into two 12-hour cycles based on sunrise and sunset, rather than using midnight as the reference point like the Western system. This creates a 6-hour offset between Ethiopian local time and international time (UTC+3, also called East Africa Time).
The Ethiopian day operates with two distinct cycles:

items: Daytime Cycle: Begins at dawn (12:00 local time, approximately 6:00 AM EAT) and runs until dusk (11:59:59 local time, approximately 5:59:59 PM EAT)
Nighttime Cycle: Begins at dusk (12:00 local time, approximately 6:00 PM EAT) and runs until dawn (11:59:59 local time, approximately 5:59:59 AM EAT)

data.text: This means the clock resets to 12:00 twice per day—at sunrise and sunset—rather than once at midnight.

points: Sunrise and sunset are the reference points

parts.title: Converting Between Ethiopian and International Time

data.text: The 6-hour offset between systems creates straightforward conversions. When someone in Addis Ababa says 'meet at two,' they mean 2:00 in their local cycle, which corresponds to 8:00 AM Western time.
If a meeting is scheduled for '3:00 Ethiopian time' during the day, that's 9:00 AM international time. If it's '3:00' at night, that's 9:00 PM international time.

parts.title: Why Ethiopian Time Starts at Dawn

data.text: This system originated from ancient agrarian practices, where daylight dictated daily rhythm and activities were coordinated around sunrise and sunset rather than arbitrary clock hours.

Ethiopia's proximity to the equator means daylight and nighttime are each approximately 12 hours year-round, making this system particularly practical. The agricultural lifestyle required coordination with natural light cycles, not abstract clock hours.

Despite its ancient roots, modern Ethiopia uses both systems interchangeably. Government offices, schools, banks, and businesses operate using dual calendars and time displays. Smartphones default to local time formats while maintaining international time compatibility.

points: Both systems coexist in modern Ethiopia
